0.paragraph: Describe the address of the VHI site: Former Residences, 5-27 Kororoit Creek Road, which is located at 5-27 Kororoit Creek Road, Williamstown, Victoria, in one paragraph.

\x0c1.0 INTRODUCTION

1 

1.1 Preamble 

This report presents the results of recent archaeological investigations at the Former Residences, 5-
27 Kororoit Creek Road (H7822-2391) conducted under heritage consent C1609 (Appendix 1). Andrew 
Long and Associates (ALA) were engaged by the Western Program Alliance (WPA) on behalf of the 
Level  Crossing  Removal  Project  (LXRP)  to  undertake  test  excavations  within  the  Victorian  Heritage 
Inventory (VHI) site: Former Residences, 5-27 Kororoit Creek Road (H7822-2391), in association with 
the Ferguson Street, Williamstown level crossing removal.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5183_H7822-2391_FinalReport_270422.pdf'}

page_content='5.2 Comparable VHI sites 

3-39 Nelson Place, Williamstown (West) H7822-2324 

Andrew  Long  +  Associates  was  commissioned  by  Evolve  Development  Pty.  Ltd.  To  undertake 
archaeological investigations at 3-39 Nelson Place, (approximately 3.1km from the VHI site: Former 
Residences,  5-27  Kororoit  Creek  Road  (H7822-2391)).  Archaeological  evidence  of  19th  century 
domestic structures and a 19th century scatter of artefacts behind the Oriental Hotel were identified 
during test excavations and the area behind the original Oriental Hotel was targeted for archaeological 
investigation.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5183_H7822-2391_FinalReport_270422.pdf'}

page_content='The  archaeological  potential  of  the  VHI  site  was  borne  out.  Historical,  in-situ  features,  like  the 
bluestone  footings  [005]  and  timber  post  [006]  associated  with  former  residence  No.  25  Kororoit 
Creek Road, were deemed to be of high significance. Contexts (003) and (004) located to the east of 
the  blue  stone  footings  [005]  demonstrated  that  there  are  at  a  minimum,  intact  pockets  of 
archaeology within the site directly related to the 19th century to early 20th century occupation of the 
former residences. Due to the earlier demolition on the eastern side of the site, there is a greater 
potential for more intact pockets of archaeology to be found. Soil profiling indicated the site may have 
been  more  disturbed  in  some  areas;  however,  the  presence  of  ground  surface  features  identified 
during the site survey suggests that despite this disturbance, archaeology is present throughout the' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5183_H7822-2391_FinalReport_270422.pdf'}

1.paragraph: The former residences of 5-27 Kororoit Creek Road, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia, are located approximately 10 kilometers southwest of the Melbourne city center, in the suburb of Southbank.
source:
page_content='1.4 Personnel  

The archaeological investigations and subsequent reporting were undertaken by Rebekka Hocking (Senior Project 
Manager, Andrew Long and Associates) and Haley Geiberras (Assistant Project Manager), with assistance in the field 
from Belle Leslie (Project Archaeologist) and Nell Sexton (Project Archaeologist).  

1.5 Legislative Requirements  

Heritage  Victoria  is  the  State  Government  body  that  administers  the  Heritage  Act  2017  (Vic).  The  Act  serves  to 
protect all categories of historical cultural heritage relating to non-Aboriginal settlement of Victoria that includes 
historic buildings, shipwrecks and archaeological sites. One of the purposes of the Heritage Act 2017 is to provide 
protection,  conservation  and  registration  for  all  archaeological  artefacts  and  sites  in  Victoria,  as  well  as  the 
establishment of the Heritage Council, Victorian Heritage Register (VHR) and the Victorian Heritage Inventory. 

Victorian Heritage Register' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5183_H7822-2391_FinalReport_270422.pdf'}

page_content='3.3 Methodology  

Following  the  methodology  outlined  in  the  Former  Residences,  5-27  Kororoit  Creek  Road,  Consent 
Application:  Supporting  Documentation  (Hocking,  2020)  and  Conditions  6-11  of  Heritage  Victoria 
issued Consent C1609 (Appendix 1), soil profiling and one test trench were undertaken between 11th-
13th January 2021. The excavations were supervised by nominated archaeologist, Rebekka Hocking, 
with assistance from archaeologists, Belle Leslie, and Nell Sexton.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5183_H7822-2391_FinalReport_270422.pdf'}

page_content='The  archaeological  potential  of  the  VHI  site  was  borne  out.  Historical,  in-situ  features,  like  the 
bluestone  footings  [005]  and  timber  post  [006]  associated  with  former  residence  No.  25  Kororoit 
Creek Road, were deemed to be of high significance. Contexts (003) and (004) located to the east of 
the  blue  stone  footings  [005]  demonstrated  that  there  are  at  a  minimum,  intact  pockets  of 
archaeology within the site directly related to the 19th century to early 20th century occupation of the 
former residences. Due to the earlier demolition on the eastern side of the site, there is a greater 
potential for more intact pockets of archaeology to be found. Soil profiling indicated the site may have 
been  more  disturbed  in  some  areas;  however,  the  presence  of  ground  surface  features  identified 
during the site survey suggests that despite this disturbance, archaeology is present throughout the' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5183_H7822-2391_FinalReport_270422.pdf'}

2.paragraph: The archaeology site is located at the intersection of Kororoit Creek Road and Lake Avenue, in Geelong, Victoria.

during the site survey suggests that despite this disturbance, archaeology is present throughout the' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5183_H7822-2391_FinalReport_270422.pdf'}

page_content='Victorian Heritage Inventory 

The  VHI  exists  under  the  Heritage  Act  2017  and  provides  protection  to  places  or  objects  identified  as  historical 
archaeological sites, areas or relics on the register, as well as all known areas where artefacts are located or occur 
and any private collections which include archaeological artefacts. 

•  The Act provides blanket protection for all historical archaeological places in Victoria that are 75 years old 

or more.  

•  The VHI is a statutory listing of all known historical archaeological sites in Victoria, except for Commonwealth 

owned/managed places, which do not fall within Heritage Victoria jurisdiction. 

•  The  VHI  includes  sites  whose  archaeological  significance  ranges  from  low  to  high,  including  places  with 

archaeological potential.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5183_H7822-2391_FinalReport_270422.pdf'}

3.paragraph: The excavation site is located in the City of Melbourne, specifically within the local government area of the former St Kilda municipality.

page_content='LXRP 
Christopher Mullan 

Western Program Alliance 
Ryan Thomas 
James Crewe 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0cEXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

Introduction 

This  report  presents  the  findings  of  recent  archaeological  investigations  conducted  under  Heritage  Victoria 
issued Consent C1609, by Andrew Long and Associates (ALA) on behalf of the Level Crossing Removal Project 
(LXRP). Ground disturbing works were required throughout the Victorian Heritage Inventory (VHI) site: Former 
Residences, 5-27 Kororoit Creek Road (H7822-2391) to build a site compound to facilitate the removal of the 
Ferguson Street, Williamstown level crossing. 

Historical Background' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5183_H7822-2391_FinalReport_270422.pdf'}

page_content='2 | P a g e  

 
 
 
\x0cFigure 2: Demonstrating the portion of the VHI site (H7822-2391) to be impacted by the proposed works. 

3 | P a g e  

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0c1.3 Scope of Works 

The following section outlines the scope of the works as provided by WPA. LXRP will oversee the removal of the 
most  dangerous  and  congested  level  crossings  on  the  metropolitan  rail  network.  The  project  will  lower  the 
Williamstown railway line under Ferguson Street resulting in the removal of the level crossing. A site compound was 
constructed at 9-27 Kororoit Creek Road to facilitate the level crossing removal works. 

The proposed impact on land surfaces within the VHI site included the following works: 

•  Mechanical stripping of top 150mm of topsoil from the entire site in preparation for construction. 
•  Excavation of up to 600mm for service trenches in the north-eastern corner of the property (combination of 

non-destructive digging (NDD) and mechanical excavation).' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5183_H7822-2391_FinalReport_270422.pdf'}
